title: Pediatric Asthma Detection with Google's HeAR Model: An AI-Driven Respiratory Sound Classifier
author: Abul Ehtesham (Kent State University), Saket Kumar (Northeastern University), Aditi Singh (Cleveland State University), Tala Talaei Khoei (Northeastern University), ...
relevance_why: The methods employed for audio classification and respiratory sound analysis can be adapted to Haohe Liu's work in audio processing, particularly in enhancing diagnostic tools using machine learning in healthcare.
background: Detecting asthma in children by analyzing respiratory sounds through an AI model designed to classify various types of wheezing and normal sounds.
contribution: This study introduces an AI-powered diagnostic pipeline using Google's Health Acoustic Representations to classify pediatric respiratory sounds, achieving over 91% accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional methods for diagnosing asthma in children often rely on invasive or subjective techniques like spirometry and auscultation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by utilizing a robust foundation audio model to classify respiratory sounds non-invasively and effectively, demonstrating high accuracy with minimal audio data.

key_innovation: Employs embeddings generated from a large, pretrained model to classify short audio clips of pediatric respiratory sounds efficiently.
real_world_impact: The method has the potential to enhance asthma screening in low-resource settings, improving healthcare access and early detection among children.
limitations: The authors do not explicitly mention any limitations.

new_terms.Health Acoustic Representations: **Health Acoustic Representations** is a model developed by Google for analyzing health-related acoustic signals, trained on a large dataset of health audio clips including cough sounds.
new_terms.SPRSound dataset: **SPRSound dataset** is an open-access collection of pediatric respiratory sounds with annotations, providing a benchmark for respiratory sound classification.

open_sourcing: The SPRSound dataset is open-access and available for use in research.
